TOTAL: All products is the sum of all energy products and is composed of the following fuel families: Solid fuels (coal), total petroleum products (crude oil and derived petroleum products), gas, nuclear heat, heat, renewable energies, electricity and non-renewable waste.
SFF_P1000: Solid fuels are fossil fuels covering various types of coals and solid products derived from coals. They consist of carbonised vegetable matter and usually have the physical appearance of a black or brown rock.
O4000: Oil and petroleum products are fossil fuels (usually in liquid state) and include crude oil and all products derived from it (e.g. when processed in oil refineries), including motor gasoline, diesel oil, fuel oil, etc.
G3000_C0350-370: Gas includes mostly natural gas and derived gases.
N900H: Nuclear heat is the thermal energy produced in a nuclear power plant (nuclear energy). It is obtained from the nuclear fission of atoms, usually of uranium and plutonium.
H8000: Heat is used for warming spaces and for industrial processes and is obtained by burning combustible fuels like coal, natural gas, oil, renewables (biofuels) and wastes, or also by transforming electricity to heat in electric boilers or heat pumps.
RA000: Renewable energies are energy sources that replenish (or renew) themselves naturally, such as solar, wind, hydro, geothermal, biomass and renewable wastes, etc.
E1_1_2: Primary production is the extraction of energy products from natural sources to a usable form. It occurs within the territory under consideration.
E1_1_1: Recovered and recycled products regroup several categories, like supply of renewable energy commodities produced in other fuel balances or certain petroleum products which are reprocessed and recycled.
N1_1: Production is the sum of primary production and recovered and recycled products.
E1_2: Imports cover the amount of energy produced outside and brought into the considered territory for consumption.
E1_3: Stock draw is the energy taken from storage facilities (e.g. gas storage vessels). It represents a positive variation of stock changes.
E1_4: Statistical difference - inflow represents the negative statistical difference, that is the negative difference between the energy available for final consumption and final consumption.
N1: Available from all sources is the addition of production, imports, stock draw and inflow of statistical difference.
N5: Direct carry-over represents the energy quantities that do not go through any transformation process (i.e. energy commodities which are used in their original form).
T2: Transformation is the total amount of energy involved in all activities where one energy commodity is transformed into a different one (e.g. natural gas transformed into electricity in a power plant).
N2_1: Transformation input is the sum of energy inputs to all transformation processes (for example, crude oil for refineries to produce derived products or natural gas for power plants to produce electricity).
T2_6: Transformation - Refineries and petrochemical industry is the transformation of crude oil and other intermediary products into refined petroleum products (like gasoline, diesel oil, fuel oil, lubricants, etc.) in refineries or the transformation of energy carriers during the production of petrochemicals (chemical products derived from petroleum) in the petrochemical industry.
N2_6_1: Transformation - Refineries and petrochemical industry input is the input of energy carriers into the transformation of crude oil and other intermediary products into refined petroleum products (like gasoline, diesel oil, fuel oil, lubricants, etc.) in refineries or during the production of petrochemicals (chemical products derived from petroleum) in the petrochemical industry.
N2_6_2: Transformation - Refineries and petrochemical industry output is the output of energy carriers from the transformation of crude oil and other intermediary products into refined petroleum products (like gasoline, diesel oil, fuel oil, lubricants, etc.) in refineries or during the production of petrochemicals (chemical products derived from petroleum) in the petrochemical industry.
T2_6_1: Transformation - Refineries is the transformation of crude oil and other intermediary products into refined petroleum products (like gasoline, diesel oil, fuel oil, lubricants, etc.).
T2_6_2: Transformation - Petrochemical industry is the transformation of energy carriers during the production of petrochemicals (chemical products derived from petroleum) in the petrochemical industry.
T2_6_3: Transformation - Refineries and petrochemical industry - Other covers other transformations of energy carriers in the refinery and petrochemical sector which are not covered in the previous sectors.
T2_7: Transformation - BKB / PB Plants are plants used to produce brown coal briquettes and peat briquettes, which are bricks composed of shredded peat or brown coal, compressed to form a slow-burning, easily stored and transported fuel.
T2_8: Transformation - Coke Ovens is the transformation of coal into coke-oven-coke, which is the most important raw material for blast furnaces and some other by-products such as coke oven gas.
T2_9: Transformation - Blast-furnaces is the transformation of coke-oven-coke into blast furnace gas, a by-product of coal consumed in blast furnaces in the reduction process of iron ores.
T2_10: Transformation - Gas works is the transformation of fuels into gas works gas, which is a flammable gas.
T2_11: Electricity and heat generation includes the production of electricity and/or heat, including renewable energies, like hydro power, wind power and solar photovoltaic, which are transformed into electricity, or the energy transformed in nuclear or thermal power plants (e.g. burning of oil, coal, gas and biofuels) to produce electricity and/or heat, or District heating plants, which are central locations used to produce district heat that is distributed through a network and may be used for process or space heating purposes.
N2_11_1: Electricity and heat generation input is the input of energy carriers for the production of electricity and/or heat, including renewable energies, like hydro power, wind power and solar photovoltaic, which are transformed into electricity, or the input of energy into nuclear or thermal power plants (e.g. burning of oil, coal, gas and biofuels) to produce electricity and/or heat, or District heating plants, which are central locations used to produce district heat that is distributed through a network and may be used for process or space heating purposes.
N2_11_2: Electricity and heat generation output is the output of electricity and/or heat from renewable energies, like hydro power, wind power and solar photovoltaic, from nuclear or thermal power plants (e.g. burning of oil, coal, gas and biofuels) or from District heating plants, which are central locations used to produce district heat that is distributed through a network and may be used for process or space heating purposes.
T2_11_1: Electricity only includes the production of electricity (without producing heat), including renewable energies, like hydro power, wind power and solar photovoltaic, which are transformed into electricity, or the energy transformed in nuclear or thermal power plants (e.g. burning of oil, coal, gas and biofuels) to produce electricity.
T2_11_2: Combined heat and power includes the combined production of electricity and heat, including nuclear or thermal power plants (e.g. burning of oil, coal, gas and biofuels) to produce a combination of both electricity and heat.
T2_11_3: Heat only includes the production of heat (without producing electricity), including e.g. district heating plants, which are central locations used to produce district heat that is distributed through a network and may be used for process or space heating purposes.
T2_11_4: Other includes the production of electricity and/or heat in transformation processes not covered in the rest of categories.
T2_12: Other transformation includes, among other, the following categories: patent fuel plants, coal liquefaction plants, for blended natural gas, charcoal production plants (transformation), gas-to-liquids (GTL) plants (transformation), non-specified transformation input.
N3: Transformation backflow includes all energy commodities that are obtained as outputs from transformation processes but are used as an input to other transformation processes, for example fuels returned from the petrochemical sector to refineries for further processing/blending.
E4: Transformation losses represent energy not accounted (lost) during the transformation processes. It is calculated as the differences between total input and total output of each transformation flow.
N2_2: Transformation output is the sum of energy obtained as a result of all transformation processes (for example, refined petroleum products from a refinery or electricity from a power plant).
N6: Available after transformation is the addition of direct carry-over and net transformation output (i.e. transformation output minus the backflow) and thus represents energy quantities that are available for use.
E6_2: Stock build is the energy stored in storage facilities (e.g. gas storage vessels). It represents a negative variation of stock changes.
E6_3: Exports represent energy quantities produced or transformed in the considered territory which are sent abroad.
E6_4: International marine bunkers represent fuel consumption of ships during international navigation.
E6_5: Consumption of the energy branch is the energy consumed to operate installations for energy production and transformation.
E6_5_1: Consumption of the energy branch - Electricity and heat generation is the energy consumed to operate installations for the production of electricity and heat.
E6_5_2: Consumption of the energy branch - Coal mines is the energy consumed to operate installations for energy production and transformation in coal mines.
E6_5_3: Consumption of the energy branch - Oil and natural gas extraction plants is the energy consumed to operate installations for energy production and transformation in oil and natural gas extraction plants.
E6_5_4: Consumption of the energy branch - Patent fuel plants is the energy consumed to operate installations for energy production and transformation in patent fuel plants.
E6_5_5: Consumption of the energy branch - Coke ovens is the energy consumed to operate installations for energy production and transformation in coke ovens.
E6_5_6: Consumption of the energy branch - Brown coal briquettes and peat briquettes plants, is the energy consumed to operate installations for energy production and transformation in brown coal briquettes and peat briquettes plants.
E6_5_7: Consumption of the energy branch - Gas works is the energy consumed to operate installations for energy production and transformation in gas works.
E6_5_8: Consumption of the energy branch - Blast furnaces is the energy consumed to operate installations for energy production and transformation in blast furnaces.
E6_5_9: Consumption of the energy branch - Oil refineries is the energy consumed to operate installations for energy production and transformation in oil refineries.
E6_5_10: Consumption of the energy branch - Nuclear industry is the energy consumed to operate installations for energy production and transformation in nuclear installations.
E6_5_11: Consumption of the energy branch - Coal liquefaction plants is the energy consumed to operate installations for energy production and transformation in coal liquefaction plants.
E6_5_12: Consumption of the energy branch - Liquefaction and regasification plants (LNG) is the energy consumed to operate installations for energy production and transformation in liquefaction and regasification plants (LNG).
E6_5_13: Consumption of the energy branch - Gasification plants for biogas is the energy consumed to operate installations for energy production and transformation in gasification plants for biogas.
E6_5_14: Consumption of the energy branch - Gas-to-liquids plants is the energy consumed to operate installations for energy production and transformation in gas-to-liquids plants.
E6_5_15: Consumption of the energy branch - Charcoal production plants is the energy consumed to operate installations for energy production and transformation in charcoal production plants.
E6_5_16: Consumption of the energy branch - Not elsewhere specified is the energy consumed to operate installations for energy production and transformation in other energy branch sectors.
E6_6: Distribution and transmission losses include, for instance, energy losses due to transport or distribution of electricity, heat, gas, as well as pipeline losses.
E6_7: International aviation covers quantities of aviation fuels delivered to aircraft for international aviation (e.g. jet kerosene consumption during international flights).
E6_8: Statistical difference - outflow represents the positive statistical difference, that is the positive difference between the energy available for final consumption and final consumption.
N6_1: Final consumption is the addition of final non-energy consumption and final energy consumption.
N6_1_2: Final non-energy consumption covers certain fuels used for non-energy purposes, for instance oil used as timber preservative.
E6_1_2_1: Final non-energy consumption - Industry covers quantities used for non-energy purposes in the industry sector, for instance coal used to make methanol or ammonia.
E6_1_2_2: Final non-energy consumption - Transport covers quantities used for non-energy purposes in the transport sector, for instance lubricants for cars.
E6_1_2_3: Final non-energy consumption - Other sectors covers quantities used for non-energy purposes, for example, in the energy sector, in the transformation sector and in other sectors, for instance asphalt in road construction.
N6_1_1: Final energy consumption covers all fuels used for energy purposes in the industry (e.g. steam used to support industrial plant activities), transport (e.g. motor gasoline used in vehicles), residential (e.g. electricity used at home), commercial/services (e.g. natural gas used for heating a public school), agriculture (e.g. diesel oil used in tractors), fishing (e.g. fuels used by coastal fishing boats) and other sectors (e.g. military energy use).
N6_1_1_1: Final energy consumption – Industry covers all fuels used for energy purposes in the industry sector (e.g. steam used to support industrial plant activities).
E6_1_1_1_1: Final energy consumption – Industry - Iron and Steel covers all fuels used for energy purposes in the iron and steel industry (e.g. steam used to support a blast furnace).
E6_1_1_1_2: Final energy consumption – Industry - Chemical and Petrochemical covers all fuels used for energy purposes in the chemical and petrochemical industry (e.g. petroleum products used as a fuel in a refinery).
E6_1_1_1_3: Final energy consumption – Industry - Non-Ferrous Metals covers all fuels used for energy purposes in the non-ferrous metals industry (e.g. fuel oil used to heat bauxite in the aluminium industry)
E6_1_1_1_4: Final energy consumption – Industry - Non-Metallic Minerals covers all fuels used for energy purposes in the non- metallic minerals industry (e.g. coal used to heat limestone and clay in the cement industry).
E6_1_1_1_5: Final energy consumption – Industry - Transport Equipment covers all fuels used for energy purposes to manufacture motor vehicles, ships, trains, planes and other (e.g. electricity used to power a robot in a car manufacturing company).
E6_1_1_1_6: Final energy consumption – Industry - Machinery covers all fuels used for energy purposes to manufacture machinery, computers, optical and electrical equipment, etc. or the (e.g. electricity used to power a robot in a computer chip manufacturing company).
E6_1_1_1_7: Final energy consumption – Industry - Mining and Quarrying covers all fuels used for energy purposes in the ore-extraction industry (e.g. fuel used to power a rock crusher machine in a granite quarry plant).
E6_1_1_1_8: Final energy consumption – Industry - Food and Tobacco covers all fuels used for energy purposes in the food and tobacco industry (e.g. steam used in a UHT treatment to sterilise dairy products in the milk industry).
E6_1_1_1_9: Final energy consumption – Industry - Paper, Pulp and Print covers all fuels used for energy purposes in the paper, pulp and print industry (e.g. electricity used to power a belt conveyor in a paper manufacturing company).
E6_1_1_1_10: Final energy consumption – Industry - Wood and Wood Products covers all fuels used for energy purposes to manufacture wood and wood products, excluding paper (e.g. electricity used to power a wood-saw for the production of assembled parquet floors)
E6_1_1_1_11: Final energy consumption – Industry - Construction covers all fuels used for energy purposes in the construction, demolition and civil engineering sectors (e.g. gasoline used to power a demolition bulldozer).
E6_1_1_1_12: Final energy consumption – Industry - Textile and Leather covers all fuels used for energy purposes in the textile and leather industry (e.g. electricity used to power a leather drying machine).
E6_1_1_1_13: Final energy consumption – Industry - Non-specified (Industry) covers all fuels used for energy purposes in other not covered industry sectors.
N6_1_1_2: Final energy consumption - Transport covers the energy used for all transport activities (e.g. electricity in rail, liquid fossil fuels in road, kerosene in aviation, fuel oil in domestic navigation, etc.).
E6_1_1_2_1: Final energy consumption – Transport - Rail covers the energy used for rail transport activities (e.g. electricity in rail traffic or electrified urban transport systems).
E6_1_1_2_2: Final energy consumption – Transport - Road covers the energy used for the propulsion of road vehicles (e.g. gasoline or diesel oil for cars).
E6_1_1_2_4: Final energy consumption – Transport - Domestic aviation covers quantities of aviation fuels delivered to aircraft for domestic aviation (e.g. jet kerosene consumption during domestic flights).
E6_1_1_2_5: Final energy consumption – Transport - Domestic Navigation covers quantities delivered to vessels of all flags not engaged in international navigation (e.g. fuel oil consumed by a ship in a journey between 2 ports of the same country).
E6_1_1_2_6: Final energy consumption – Transport - Consumption in Pipeline transport covers the energy used to support and operate pipelines transporting gases, liquids and other commodities (e.g. energy used to pump natural gas through a pipeline).
E6_1_1_2_7: Final energy consumption – Transport - Non-specified (Transport) covers quantities used for transport activities not covered elsewhere (e.g. fuels used in ports for ships' unloaders).
N6_1_1_3: Final energy consumption – Other sectors covers quantities consumed by sectors not belonging to energy, industry or transport (e.g. energy consumed in private households, commerce, administrative bodies, etc.).
E6_1_1_3_1: Final energy consumption - Other Sectors - Services covers energy consumed by business and offices in the public and private sectors (e.g. electricity consumed by a public administrative building or heating oil consumed in a private school).
E6_1_1_3_2: Final energy consumption - Other Sectors - Households covers energy consumed by all households (e.g. electricity for lighting and powering domestic appliances, heating fuels like gas, wood or gasoil, etc.).
E6_1_1_3_3: Final energy consumption - Other Sectors - Agriculture/Forestry covers energy consumed for agriculture, hunting and forestry (e.g. diesel consumed by tractors).
E6_1_1_3_4: Final energy consumption - Other Sectors - Fishing covers energy consumed for inland, coastal and deep-sea fishing (e.g. fuel oil consumed by a fishing boat).
E6_1_1_3_5: Final energy consumption - Other Sectors - Non-specified (Other) consists of final energy consumption not classified under any other code (e.g. military energy use).
